Definition: Output the result as "Toxic" if the given sentence is rude, disrespectful, or inappropriate otherwise output as "Non-toxic".

Positive Examples.input:

Comment: There are two grievous flaws in the ignorant and idiotic statement "if you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear."

Firstly, it is not for YOU to decide what you do or do not have to hide --- that decision, rightly or wrongly (and it is mostly the latter) is in the hands of those in power, i.e. the government and their agents.  And more and more, they are deciding that you, we, DO have something to hide.

Secondly, effectively EVERYONE has something to hide, whether they realize it or not, due to the vast and ever-growing web of onerous and intrusive laws and regulations, particularly on the federal level.  It has been estimated that the average person breaks the law at least five times every day.  So anyone who dares to publicly speak out or resist those (unjust) laws will surely invite those in power to scrutinize their life and their past activities in order to find something with which to prosecute that person, particularly in this day of the death of privacy.

Comment: Now that's an idiotic & ignorant remark if I've ever read one! "Just stop smoking. I didn't need the patch or anything". Simply because the "cold turkey" approach worked for you doesn't mean that it'll work for everyone! Your sweeping "analysis" doesn't account for a myriad other critical considerations: how long the individual has smoked, the number of cigarettes that person has typically consumed in a given day over that period, the actual strength/nicotine level of the favoured cigarette brand, the rate at which each cigarette is consumed, full or partial consumption, the conditions/settings where the smoking typically takes place (socially or universally, post-meals, with meals, with alcohol, with coffee,  post-sexual activity, etc.), filtered vs plain cigarettes, the reason the individual started smoking & continues to do so (peer pressure, social rebellion, stress relief) & the subjective length & severity of withdrawl symptoms.

In other words, your claims are baseless & facile!

Comment: As an erstwhile writer, I cannot but agree with the author.

The 'cultural appropriation' crowd would have us all sequestered into our own little boxes, labeled with our sexuality, labeled with our racial background, labeled with our sex, and from that box we are graciously 'allowed' to write. Screw empathy. Screw exploration of concepts or cultures. Screw curiosity or, gasp, failure. The concept that we're all trying to transcend those all-too-limited labels seems to be lost on them.

If I write a novel with an indigenous character and I don't do the character justice, the proper solution is to educate me, show me where I went wrong, illustrate how my characterization could have been more accurate, give me better descriptions of native concepts or a clearer picture into their world.

But to tell me I can't write that character in the first place?  How small minded.  How petty. How controlling.

Comment: "who do you think should do the killing?"

Anyone and everyone. This is a community problem, so everyone who wants to be part of the solution should be allowed to help. Comment: TOTALLY agree. I didn't wanna jump on it that hard, as Kami's a Broncos fan & agreed w/your overall point. 
The stat about teams' success when their bell-cow, or entire team, has X amount of carries, is silly, & reverse engineering.
Of COURSE teams win % is going to be generally higher in games where they rush it more.
1. When we're ahead, we're going to rush the ball more to milk the clock. I'll bet there's a GINORMOUS correlation between 4th quarter carries & winning %.
MORE importantly, 
2. Continuing to run the ball when we're averaging 1.5 yards a carry is going to ensure that we're continually be PUNTING the ball. 
And on the FLIP side, 
3. If we're averaging 6 yards per carry we're gonna have a LOT fewer 3rd & longs, & are gonna keep running it, since it's a LOT safer than passing. Turnovers aside, it's virtually impossible to LOSE a game when successfully running it.
THAT'S why teams who've won have more carries. Not because they rushed it just to hit 20 carries.

Comment: The establishment of the preserve established the basic framework for what eventually became the Papahanaumokuakea Marine National Monument. It's not bragging. It's pointing out an important initiative that the Council is never given credit. It's important to note that this happened 15 years before the PMNM was declared and clearly makes WesPac the first agency to do so much in the name of conservation.

Since that point, coral reefs have been protected in that region out to a range of 50 miles beyond the shores of those islands and atolls. Zero monk seal interactions with longline boats in the past 10 years. There are so many "apex predators", also known as sharks, that the monk seals are having a hard time maintaining their numbers in the PMNM. 

Every conservation organization has deemed the PMNM "pristine". That means that any activities taking place in that area up until now has had more or less zero impact.

These are all published, verifiable facts. Please do some research.

Comment: Like the title, Prophetic Obedience, and what it conjures for my perception. Not convinced to read after review as it seems to delve into a lot of theological hair splitting. The concept of the "People of God" like "We the People" sought to invest authority within the common good of the masses rather than a select few men at the top. It remains fiercely resisted by the few men at the top, in church and state. Obedience linguistically has origins in "listening to." The collegial, democratic impulse is that servant-leaders listen to the people more than forcing the people to listen to them. The elites still distrust the masses to know what is good and good for them. Was it Freire who said not to capitulate "that the masses are asses?" Voices from below still struggle to have their voices heard. Paul VI's rejection of the birth control commission is currently exhibit A. The masses need to believe in their prophetic voice despite efforts from above to silence them.

Comment: What you are describing sounds more like gambling than a carefully thought out investment strategy. People should stretch themselves to take on a million dollar liability in the hopes that houses will continue to go up forever? Comment: " It has no paved roads, formal street names or addresses — but has stunning views of Pearl Harbor and beyond."

"...Romy Mindo, who has largely given up farming his lot there because of difficulties in getting sufficient water."

The primary problem isn't failure to enforce ag zoning restrictions, it's that this parcel should not be zoned Ag1 in the first place. Nearly all of it is sloped/steeply sloped, gullied, rocky, dry, poor soil, inadequate water, no irrigation infrastructure. It's been officially designated inferior land for agriculture.  It cannot be profitably farmed, especially if owners/lessees have to pay to live elsewhere and commute back and forth on top of usual farming costs. This is the crux of the matter. 

If these working-class owners had the money and political connections of DR Horton or other developers, C&C would have assigned proper zoning a long time ago (small ag parcels with one dwelling allowed?). We need affordable housing and this land is good for that.

Comment: From the SCC in the Ewanchuk case: "The absence of consent, however, is purely subjective and determined by reference to the complainant’s subjective internal state of mind towards the touching, at the time it occurred.  While the complainant’s testimony is the only source of direct evidence as to her state of mind, credibility must still be assessed by the trier of fact in light of all the evidence.  It is open to the accused to claim that the complainant’s words and actions, before and during the incident, raise a reasonable doubt against her assertion that she, in her mind, did not want the sexual touching to take place."

What is in the victim's mind is indeed part of the analysis but, as I've stated already, messages that pertain to the determination should be admissible. That does not mean that any and all text messages between the victim and the accused ought to be admitted.

Comment: Income sprinkling is indeed a strategy that is practically only available to high income earners.  Here is how avoidance strategies work, generally.  Professional tax accountants at various degrees on the ethical scale intimately understand the tax code, and their job is to develop strategies for avoiding tax, and this is done for the benefit of high income earners, who assume the burden of the cost of performing this intellectual work.  Poor people can't pay for it.  Once a strategy is devised and used successfully, everyone in the profession gets to know it. The government, for its part,  is constantly trying to combat these tax avoidance strategies, which are legal.  That's how the game is played. Surely income sprinkling to 'not at arms length' shareholders, who receive a return from a business, and have not actually made any financial investment, is purely an arrangement set up to save tax, and serves no other purpose.  And ... is only used by high income earners.

Comment: There are several layers of law involved when it comes to land use. Starting from the top, federal law. Indian, or native Hawaiian, land is regulated by federal law. State law. Some country and city land use is regulated by state law, which sometimes overlaps with local law. Local law is C&C of Honolulu. Lowest down the ladder is neighborhood law, in this case, Neighborhood Board "law" - which is really a patchwork of what a person living in the neighborhood wants and does not want. The north shore doesn't want any native property use because that brings in federal law and crimes are not permissible under federal law the same way they are permissible under local law levels due to who you know and what strings you can pull. If this was native land use, no one would be able to control it except the feds.

Comment: "The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is warning people that a daily aspirin regimen may not help prevent a heart attack or stroke, and may cause dangerous bleeding into the BRAIN or stomach.

Although a daily low dose of aspirin has been shown to be effective in preventing a reoccurrence of a heart attack or stroke, the FDA is now warning people who have not had a first heart attack or stroke that taking an aspirin every day may not have a benefit. In fact, doing so may actually cause serious side effects.

However, following examination of scientific data from major studies, the FDA has concluded that the data do not support the use of aspirin as a preventive medication by people who have not had a heart attack, stroke, or cardiovascular problems, a use that is known as primary prevention. In these people, the benefit has not been established, and risks, such as dangerous bleeding into the BRAIN or stomach, are still present." 
                FDA, 2014

Not true. They continue to add branches off the other existing terminals. And I consider an entire new terminal to be "loads" of room. I lived there for 15 years and never had any of the problems you describe. Especially now with Pre, you are literally 10 minutes between car and plane, whether coming or going. Having the gates just on the other side of security significantly reduces the time compared to DEN. On a GOOD day at DEN you are 30 minutes from your car upon arrival, often longer. Disconnected concourses serve no benefit to the traveler, it's a horrible design flaw.

Yes there can be long taxis at DFW, as there can be at DEN as well.

Comment: AK_F-Zero tax filers in 1980 were about 20%. By 2013 it was 40% and in 2016 it was 45%.  Meanwhile, in 1979, the top 10 percent of households, as measured by income, paid 40.6 percent of all federal taxes; by 2005, the top 10 percent accounted for nearly 55 percent of all federal tax revenues. 

JP-Payroll taxes include Soc Sec, Medicare, Medicaid. The reason they are called payroll taxes rather than income taxes is the employers pay a matching amount. These payroll taxes are NOT included for state income tax calculations. I'm not talking about how much one has deducted from their check, but how much they pay in that gets kept once they file. Many folks have some tax withheld, but get it all (or more with EITC) back when they file. Using the link you provided, the two lowest quintiles show zero federal income tax. Bottom line: non-federal payers will be non-state payers and that won't help the state.

Comment: The Alaska Division of Geological & Geophysical Surveys has many recent, free, downloadable reports and maps showing the results of tsunami inundation modeling for southern coastal communities. Comment: The straw man argument that re-conveyance was touted as “the cure” misses the point. For over ten years DNR was not upholding their legal obligation to harvest Clallam owned timber, resulting in loss of revenue to the county and it’s junior taxing districts. For most of those ten years the Clallam County Board of Commissioners had a Democratic majority and the majority chose not to get DNR to uphold their legal obligation to the county. Progress on the issue was not made until Republicans Jim McEntire and Bill Peach joined the Board of Natural resources and pressed the issue with DNR. The idea of re-conveyance was considered an option, not a cure, should DNR fail to address the arrearage. Due to Republican efforts, DNR is now working the way it should and revenue is flowing to the county. Since DNR is doing their job, re-conveyance is not necessary.

Comment: 1 - The entire case of not just the Little Sisters but the other Catholic and Protestant organizations consolidated before the Supreme Court rested on the Religious Freedom Restoration Act.

Comment: It could be because I went to school in cities where there was enough urban density where I didn't need to own a car since everything was walkable or there was great transit (or the occasional cab, failing all that).  I lived for six years very easily without a car, so I know it can be done.  And with smartphones, bus tracking, trip planning, Uber/Lyft, etc., it's easier than ever before.  I took a book with me everywhere and just read while the subway or bus or cab driver took care of the driving for me - I've never read so many books in my life!  

Obviously this does not work for everyone, but it is very possible for plenty of people who still feel wedded to their cars.  And this required me changing my mentality from having grown up in Portland where we were used to driving only a couple of blocks to a friend's house instead of walking, because that's just what everyone did.

I am disgusted with some of the terrible building designs, but not the notion of density w/ low parking.

Comment: Oh, the writers do address the law, sort of, when they talk about indigenous law in passing. How many sets of indigenous laws are there? One per First Nation? Where is the legal framework, jointly agreed and captured in both indigenous and non-indigenous law? For the Canadian legal system to make any coherent sense, there has to be an agreement on who does what to whom when and to what degree the non-indigenous legal system applies to indigenous people and vice versa. Without such an agreement, there is no legal way forward and the writers cannot say whether or not the Supreme Court made the correct ruling. There's a heck of a lot of negotiating to be done between First Nations and between them and the federal government - the federal government should not be expected to make a blanket statement before such negotiations occur.

Comment: I don't know what the motivation for this "story" is but there isn't a damned thing wrong with pot-fished cod. The fish are alive and well until they are bled and put into the hold. No marks, no rot, just pristine fish.

I can pull a string of 50 pots in about 75 minutes. I get multiple fish per pot. A longliner takes the same amount of time to pull a mile of gear - they get 1 fish per hook on the best trips.  The fish density of pots is far greater given the amount of effort. Pots also do not have a sea mammal impact - at all. Longline cod has a far higher carbon footprint and a higher interaction with bycatch and sea mammals. We have had observers and federally reported statistics which support my comment since the 1990s. A very robust collection of data indeed and the evidence behind my comment is only growing with each season.

And really - change that photo. A fresh Pacific Cod looks marvelously copper and shiny... your pic is of the cod we use as hanging crab bait in pots.

Comment: I applaud the legislature's effort to cut spending. Anyone that has studies these numbers can appreciate we are spending well beyond our means. But while continued cuts are necessary, they alone cannot solve this problem. Neither can eliminating oil tax credits, imposing taxes or reducing dividends. The fact is, all of these things are needed as part a comprehensive solution, but they should be coordinated and phased in over time. 

Each year we bicker over how much we dislike this or that element, we burn reserves, reduce our options and make the impending economic impacts that much worse. On top of it all, we are now dealing with election politics, with lawmakers making various sorts of excuses for why they can't do anything more than cut. 

While I appreciate the numbers provided here by Rep. Neuman's (and no, they are not "cooked"), refusing to discuss revenue enhancements is an oversight that will cost Alaska dearly in the long run.

Comment: Pete, the site administrators can see rejected comments, but for now, users can't. It'd be an interesting idea to have a "click here to see rejected comments" button. But, since the stuff that gets rejected is typically name-calling, threats, and spam, I don't think it'd add much to the page.

It's a common concern that people will vote down dissenting opinions; that's part of why we ask "is this a *good* comment?" first. People can mark a comment as "bad", but still "civil" if they just disagree with an idea. And we have a lot going on in our backend algorithms to keep things fair/prevent bias in what gets published.

Comment: I think the real point is to make your payments more frequently based on the typical monthly amount for the amortization period divided by 2 week intervals. In other words, you make 26 bi-weekly payments equal to one-half of the monthly amount. Over the course of a year you will have made the equivalent of 13 months worth of payments thereby making the "extra" month's payment a direct reduction of the principal amount. (A weekly method would have a small additional advantage). This approach can reduce a 25 year amortization to less than 20 years in many cases.

Comment: Jon, over 10,000 district voters turned out in the 2016 general election.  Over 4,000 turned out for the 2016 Democratic primary vote for D-36 Representative.  The low voter turnout is a statewide phenomenon and not strictly limited to D-36.  

I can speculate as to why the state has such a low turnout and it's most-likely attributable to a great lack of faith in candidates (a choice issue) and a corollary to our incredibly high cost of living (where voting is a luxury when you're not  grinding to make ends meet).  

I believe Marilyn has a valid concern with Fukumoto's claim that her switching parties is motivated by 4% of the total number of voters that had cast their vote during the D-36 representative seat run-off.  

As a candidate, switching from Republican to Democrat - here in Hawai'i - means accessibility to union money and thus, a much larger campaign coffer.  Isn't that a major reason for the switch?  The feel good "community wants it" claim is just political double speak.

Comment: Unfortunately, Bjohn, your comment of "vibrant and growing" congregations of religious women is not quite as solid as you present.  In the US and throughout Europe, women religious - both contemplative and apostolic - are in and have been in a steep decline for fifty years.  In both types of orders, women who enter and make it to the profession of first vows, only a very few will stay to profess final vows.  The exact same case is true of male religious.  The growth is numbers of sisters globally is centered in developing nations - particularly Africa, the Philippines, parts of South America - and the sociocultural conditions are almost the same as what women who entered convents in the first half of the 20th century US found: very few options for women, dwindling family resources that a entrance into religious life would help alleviate, etc.  The "recently professed" and a whole lot of others have, indeed, been interviewed at length.  What do you think they know that others don't?

Comment: There was a study widely reported in the Canadian media a few years ago based on interviews conducted with, as I recall, 91 muslim women who wore such coverings. The majority stated that theirs was a matter of choice, often taken despite the objections of their families. Few expressed that it had a religious significance for them. 
If memory serves me, the primary reasons given were two-fold : to discourage the unwanted attention of strange men and to identify themselves with their ethnic origins. In most cases they were willing to remove the coverings when necessary.
The media reports shouldn't be hard to find on Google.
If the study was an accurate reflection of these women's attitudes then bill62 is an overreaction and its detractors' opinions highly exaggerated.

Comment: The problem Steven is that BC's economy rests on a foundation of resource development, agriculture and forestry. There are three ways you can create wealth.  You can make stuff, or you can grow stuff or you can dig stuff up.  You might not have noticed but these three ways of creating wealth appear to be declining in BC.  Everything else is just paper shuffling. 
Who can afford to manufacture anything outside niche industries in BC?  Forestry has just run into a Trump in the road.  Agriculture appears to be disappearing under the expanding suburbs of the Lower Mainland.  When was the last time a mine opened in BC? Or even a major dam?  Now that oil and gas development appears to be actively discouraged what's left?  Tourism?  Very seasonal and BC's high costs are discouraging.  Real Estate?  Now that's a bubble just waiting to burst.  Government Services?  That only spends wealth.  Perhaps extorting funds from other provinces in order to let them trade is all BC has left.

Comment: Your information is out of date.  The law was changed in 1993 so that it no longer conflicts with the Charter, so the Notwithstanding provision was not needed.

"On December 21, 1988, after the decision of the Supreme Court of Canada in Ford v. Quebec (A.G.), the National Assembly of Quebec employed Section 33 and the equivalent Section 52 of the Quebec Charter of Human Rights and Freedoms in their Bill 178. This allowed Quebec to continue to restrict the posting of certain commercial signs in languages other than French. In 1993, after the law was criticized by the United Nations Human Rights Committee, the Bourassa government had the National Assembly rewrite the law to conform to the Charter, and the notwithstanding clause was removed."

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Section_33_of_the_Canadian_Charter_of_Rights_and_Freedoms

Comment: Maybe there's something positive about trying to have a conversation, but let's try honesty rather than snark and finger-pointing. Comment: Many scientists are creationists.  You're acting like science and belief in God or Intelligent Design is incompatible.  No, evolution doesn't explain most of what we see in our world today.  There is no fossil record of evolution happening.  There is no common ancestor of men and apes.  Genetics shows humans have a common female ancestor (mitochondrial DNA). Physics defies evolution by showing that life and the natural world don't gradually get more complex and more orderly over time but rather devolve into disorder and degradation.  There are no vestigial organs like people once thought, like the tailbone, the appendix, the tonsils.  All of these have function.  Darwin's biggest doubt about Evolution was the sudden appearance of all modern forms of animals during the Cambrian Explosion.  He could not offer any explanation.  The coelacanth is a fish that exists today and is not a "missing link".  The archaeopteryx was not a missing link.  It was a regular perching bird.

Comment: Yes, of course the cost of Measure 97 will be passed on to consumers.  To think otherwise is delusional.  Some businesses fight the measure because it applies only to some and puts them at a disadvantage relative to the untaxed competing companies.

So to make an informed decision, we must assume that we consumers collectively will pay the bill.  The next question, given that we will pay the bill, is whether we want to give up our earned money to the state government for whatever purpose.

Keep in mind that this tax is extremely regressive.  The poor will pay a higher proportion of their income to this tax than the wealthy.  Other states have honest sales taxes that do not pretend to tax corporations.  These states often exclude necessities like food thereby mitigating the impact on the poor.  Measure 97 does not exclude necessities making its impact on the poor extreme.

In deciding, don't believe in the lie that we will not pay.

Comment: First off, unlike a lot of fruits and veggies, cannabis grows naturally all over the world including in the Canadian climate. The producers you talk about in Canada are medical producers. Medical cannabis is grown indoors in controlled conditions because it has to be medicinally pure, free from molds and other pests that are detrimental to health.
The wine industry is a better analogy to the cannabis industry.  Both grapes and cannabis produce an incredible range of flavours and are affected by their growing conditions. Compare canada's wine industry to californias. California produces hot climate wines like cabernets and chardoneys while Canada produces cool climate wines like Reisling and cab franc. Canadian wines are distinctive because of the soil and conditions they are grown in.

Same goes for pot. california has their OG, we have sweet island skunk and northern lights. Pot can be grown easily in Canada....few people do though for obvious reasons

Comment: Building new pipelines is not in the national interest, nor the world's interests. First, it is doubtful whether we will be able to sell the oil that these pipelines will carry unless we heavily discount the price of dilbit - which would make it a money-losing proposition. There is currently a glut of oil and there are good reasons to believe that this situation of oversupply will continue and perhaps even grow worse. Secondly, transporting dilbit by pipeline and tanker poses a very real ecological threat, both in terms of driving up GHG emissions from carbon-intensive bitumen production and in terms of the threat of nearly-impossible-to-clean-up dilbit spills. So, how is this in our national interest?

Comment: Fair enough, but then we should not ask taxpayers to pay for treating sports injuries and illnesses arising from poor eating habits and sedentary lifestyles, ie. almost all ER and medical treatment.

Gerald Thomas, an analyst with the Centre for Addictions Research of B.C., and Chris Davis, an analyst with the Canadian Centre on Substance Abuse, used Health Canada data to chart the health and social costs of cannabis, tobacco and alcohol. Their findings: tobacco-related health costs are over $800 per smoker per year; alcohol-related health costs are $165 per drinker per year; cannabis-related health costs are $20 per consumer per year ... under prohibition with no quality control or labeling. The health-related social costs of cannabis will go down futher when it is legally regulated. Same story with the other illegal drugs. Enforcement costs add $153 per drinker and $328 per cannabis user. In other words, 94 per cent of the cost to society of cannabis comes from keeping it illegal.

Comment: The  fact that this trial is happening at all shows me how far we have come. Gone forever are the bad old days when "whistle blowing" was routinely defined as the great sin of "Scandal." Comment: The Alaska Supreme Court's decision that Permanent Fund dividends are not an entitlement from a dedicated fund but an appropriation issue supports the approach by Mr. Bradner. Using what we have first before enacting new taxes is the approach of a good steward. Sadly, many people treat the PFD as an entitlement despite the court's decision that is firmly based on our state constitution. Because of this attitude, those same people consider a smaller appropriation for the PFD as a "taking."  However, the PFD is an expenditure of state funds and that use of state funds must compete and be balanced against all other needs. A smaller PFD is not a taking, but should be the result of a careful and thoughtful process by the governor and the legislature to meet state needs from a smaller treasury.

Comment: I'm always glad to see this topic covered in the mainstream press, something that has been a rare bird of late. As I mentioned to my good friend mc in another post, I have been independently researching this stuff for decades.

As the article makes quite plain, this is not new information. It's just not clouded in the foggy polito-speak of Foreign Affairs or some other official publication written in blurry euphamisms.

I was quite surprised in 1991-'92 to learn of a process called horizotal drilling that was being used by I believe Mobil to drill offshore into Somalia to access oil buried underneath their huge aquafir. It was a little-used technology at that time, the same technique that brought us Desert Storm.

Today you can read all about new fresh water discoveries in the region.
I have every confidence that as soon as the last drop of oil is squeezed from the Earth this type of information will find its way into high school history books.

And not a minute too soon, no?

Comment: Here in London we're seeing similar whining going on over the Shift bus rapid transit system, from downtown merchants who have formed DownShift, which seeks to force city council into  killing the project, or shifting the main route so it bypasses the core and services areas where ridership has always been low. 

Their argument is pretty much the same as what we're hearing from merchants in other cities:  "It costs too much, nobody will use it, the construction will kill our businesses or cut into sales." While I sympathize to an extent, would these same merchants try to force their cities not to make urgent road and sewer repairs that were going to take a while? 

LRT is needed because of two emerging demographic groups: millennials, who can't afford cars or don't want the bother and expense of owning and maintaining one, and the elderly who have to stop driving for medical reasons or who also cannot afford to drive. LRT will serve both groups well.

Comment: Doug, here's the deal... back in September, ADN hired me to do a poll on who Alaskans were going to vote for President, US Senate and US Congress.  The results came back showing healthy leads for Trump, Murkowski and Young.  ADN wrote articles about each of the results and published them in the paper and on this site.  They did this as a public service, because people are interested in this kind of stuff.  Now... were ADN "purporting to predict the future" in doing this like you suggest?  No, they weren't, any more than I was.  Just doing a poll, seeing what people think.

FYI, pollsters always give out information about margin of error.  Newspapers that run stories on poll results always state the margin of error.  I wouldn't call it "limits on expertise", it's just subject to error like any measurement is.

Then your last line... I'll reiterate one more time:  We. Don't. Make. Predictions.

Comment: Sheesh, this tempest would fain tip the teapot. I mean the bitter disharmony on display here, not that little letter. The letter causes nary a ripple for the powers that be.

The underlying issue--tell me if I'm wrong--is this. Belief in clear, objective rules of sin became a rallying point for rigorists. That belief is in deep trouble. You don't have to be Irish to think up a scenario--several scenarios are well known--where thwarting an ethically considered abortion would be un-Christian. And it's not hard to think of Christian exceptions to the no-communion rule for un-annulled remarrieds (we have a "quote" from You Know Who naming one exception). So good luck with objective rules. Judgment is not ours.

Can we still accompany each other? We've come to the last straws of objectivity, and those are wafting away. Soon all any of us will have left to confront will be our own failure to love. Yikes, I can sympathize! I don't like thinking about that at all.

Comment: Robert R. Paddock, thanks.

Do sprinklers significantly reduce property damage from fires in highrises?  Do sprinklers actually save lives or injuries?  

The most objective way to find out is to look at the premiums charged by companies for insurance policies for owners or renters.  If there's any difference in premiums between sprinklered and sprinkerless highrises, that difference would be an objective measure of how much value professional actuaries place on sprinklers.  

Insurance companies put their money where their mouth is.  They study how much was actually paid for property damage and loss of life, and adjust the premiums accordingly for future years.  I'll bet there's no difference.  Or if there is any difference in fire insurance premiums, compare the total difference in premiums over 30 years against the cost of retrofitting.  

Then there's the cost of moving out people and their furniture to let sprinkler pipes be installed. And the cost of asbestos removal.

Comment: Ms. Henein's article is mostly polemic. Insofar as it is reasoned, it falls victim to the fallacy of generalization. Statistical statements about populations cannot prove anything about individuals, nor can a fact about an individual prove anything about a population. Marie Henein is an accomplished litigator. That does not disprove the assertion that female lawyers are less inclined to become litigators than male lawyers. By the same token, the fact that female lawyers are less inclined to become litigators than male lawyers does not prove that Marie Henein, or any other female lawyer, is disinclined, or unsuited, to be a litigator.
In the same way, that women are less inclined to go into computer science does not prove that all women, or any particular woman, are unsuited to be software engineers. When making decisions about individuals, you should look at the  individual; Damore objects to Google making policy by groups with respect to decisions about individuals.

Thereby they exclude the vast majority of ordinary Catholics. This strange set of conditions for who can and cannot sign smacks of clubby self-aggrandizement, desperate attention-getting, and the dim recognition that no one else in the Church actually pays them attention. Rorate-Caeli has in place a similar clubby self-aggrandizing policy, seeking only the writings of either traditionalist priests or European Catholics, under the assumption that only these kinds of people know what Catholicism is!

Comment: You don't actually pay for the US channel that carries the game in which the ads are substituted by CTV for the Canadian ads.  None of your cable bill goes to these US networks. Comment: You have a good choice, you probably are using at least one of Vanguard excellent index funds.

The reason I ask, and this is true of prospectus of funds as well, is that you will see 'investor return' as critical information.  *It works well for indexing being as you have very low transaction cost and generally long term holding, not short term.

The American economic system is the envy of most of the world in our ability to raise capital for investment.   One of the ways we do this prioritize the 'return to the investor', which is where corporation go to raise money.    You lose RTI, your investors don't stick around.    (and of course investors are 'ranked' by importance as well, I have plenty of investments, but I'm not a preferred stockholder in any of them).

Cutting the corporate tax rate is fine, but not if you also cut the tax rates for those people that have will be FIRST in line for the windfall.   Exec comp is next.  Wage/benefits are last.   That's reality.

Comment: Slightly more specifically the last year that net debt decrease in Ontario was during the 2001/02 fiscal year when the Premier was Mike Harris and the Finance Minister as Jim Flaherty.

Debt also decreased in 2000/01 under Harris and Ernie Eves as Finance Minister.  It also decreased in 1999/2000 though that year it only decreased because the proceeds of leasing the 407 ETR was booked during that year.  Without those proceeds the government would have been slightly deeper in debt at the end of the 1999/00 fiscal year.

So, excluding asset sales, we have a grand sum total of TWO years where the Ontario budget was truly "balanced" in the past 35+ years.

That is a 300 mile of piping, BUT, we have longer on oil/gas lines.

Comment: They know that their fellow citizens instinctively resist rationing imposed from outside, so they promise “unlimited” care for all, which is about as realistic as promising personal unicorns for all. In the process, they also ignore the fact that many of the systems they admire are neither single-payer nor free to patients. Above and beyond the exorbitant taxes that must almost always be levied to fund their single-payer schemes, many of these countries impose other costs on patients. There are frequently co-payments, deductibles, and other cost-sharing requirements. In fact, in countries such as Australia, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, and Switzerland, consumers cover a greater portion of health-care spending out-of-pocket than do Americans. But American single-payer proposals eliminate most or all such cost-sharing. 
Bernie Sanders’s proposed “Medicare for All” system, which would have cost $13.8 trillion over its first decade of operation?

Comment: Both cancer cells and a fetus arise solely from within the host. They are not "foreign bodies." They are cells that have sprung from the genetic material of the host itself. Without the host they could neither have come into existence nor continue to exist.

There's no question that for scientific purposes we can can classify a fetus as "human," just as we can give the same classification to a human liver. But at what point a fertilized egg becomes a human entity and due all human rights is purely a LEGAL/POLITICAL matter. Science offers no guidance on that score. But if it did, it would be that ANY human cell is due all human rights, because all human cells can be cloned and become a human individual in due course.

Comment: Dejain, I take your words to mean teachers who are less burned out and who are less influenced by the billion-dollar education industry, both positive qualities in a teacher. If we provided school choice it would be teachers who would experience the biggest jump in job satisfaction and be able to teach later in life instead of jumping ship as soon as the PERS numbers make sense. 

Schools would be smaller and more independently run. Teachers could work with other teachers who share their education philosophy, which is rarely the case now. I put my kids through local schools. There was always something near a consensus among parents who the best teachers were. We reward and promote those excellent teachers.

It's also time to stop the top-down tyranny of the giant education bureaucracy. Progressives are always the first ones to point out how pluralistic our society is now, so why shouldn't they also support educational choice?

Comment: We're not that far apart on any of that, I don't think.

Definitely need to implement mandatory e-Verify. Although kinda like your wall issues, I'd hold off on the employer penalties until we see that e-Verify is really working as it should. I think one of the problems with e-Verify is holes in the data. It's not always that clear cut whether a "hit" from e-Verify is always accurate. As such, I could see a series of court challenges when it denies employment. I agree that employers need to be punished for KNOWINGLY hiring illegals, but they also need to be protected (from the govt and from job applicants) for bad data provided by the applicant and within govt databases. Probably need something like a 2-year mandatory test period before the penalties kick in.  

And while I don't want an actual "wall", I do think we need a stronger border. While jobs are surely the #1 reason, it's not the only reason illegals break into the US and stay. For instance, some break in to have a baby here.

Comment: One final point I'd make- another poster in this thread made a very accurate observation which bears repeating- forcing people to pay for any and all rescues can and has discouraged people who are in legitimate need of assistance from calling for help until such a time that the situation has worsened and resulted in an even riskier and more costly intervention. 
Rescue insurance is a better topic of conversation. Such insurance is required in Europe and is increasingly available here (through groups like the Anerican Alpine club, Global Rescue, etc.)
Climber rescues are dramatic and gain the most attention but they account for about 4 percent of rescue costs nationwide. 
Personally, I view rescue services in the same light as fire and police. Comment: Unions built the middle class in America.  Collective bargaining helped raised the living standards of millions of workers.  But union membership has been in precipitous decline for decades.  Fifty years ago, nearly a third of U.S. workers belonged to a union. Today, it's one in 10.   If the growing gap between rich and poor in this country is to be reversed, rebuilding the union movement is essential.  Union decline is not inevitable.  It has continued to grow in places like Spain, Ireland, Chile, Luxembourg and Mexico. But most unions in this country have been slow to change, to modernize, to appeal to younger workers. Some would do well to adopt the German model of cooperation with management to help grow their companies. Often American unions have presented an image of hostility and unreasonable defense of outdated conditions which earns them bad PR which in turn makes it harder for them to recruit new members. This action by UPW on its face seems to be a perfect example of that.

Comment: Voting "no" will have near-term dramatic and destructive consequences for the schools and for poor people's health. That's part of the reason the measure is before us now. To prevent that. It would be more humane and reasonable to pass it and fine-tune it later.

And, as Springor says below, making complex tax policy through the initiative process is not the preferred way to develop good tax policy. Unfortunately, the legislature has not done its work, so we have the measure. The fine-tuning needs to be done partly after the fact because this is a process. Laws are passed, and then corporations and people react to the law in ways that have unanticipated consequences. Conditions change. And putting the policy through thorough review with hearings from all the affected parties is a good process, one that can't really take place with the initiative process. Let's hope that out legislators do their work well, and let's take action if they don't.

Comment: Nick, good article.  The Brady Rule or exculpatory evidence (evidence favorable to the defendant) cannot be with held by the prosecution.  This principle is essential to a fair and honest trial. A prosecutor would not last long in the business by routinely withhold evidence.  Although, attorney's are not highly regarded... they have rules that must be followed.  Each prosecutor has a different way of presenting his case.  Outcomes at a trial can be very different depending on the quality of the prosecution. Justice is very illusive.  A trial does not guarantee justice or fairness.  Just a simple trial of before peers (or by a judge). Please remember what anything that you say can and will be used against you.  There is nothing that says anything can and will be used in your favor.  Police are not required to speak in your defense unless you call them as your witness. You tell a detective that you loved your wife but you killed her. All he is going to say is that you killed her.

Comment: No there is no statute that oversees a prosecutor's discretion. It's actually (and UNFORTUNATELY) the other way around, and contrary to common sense, that as long as the state actor operates in what he BELIEVES to be good faith, he is operating with prosecutorial immunity. It all goes back to U.S v Leon, which not only built in personal safeguards relating to law enforcement, prosecutors, and yes, even legal-clerical workers like clerks and judges, it also allows for admission of evidence which, otherwise would have been suppressed, so long as the belief that it was gathered in good faith is articulable. Here, it's not like the DA is dropping all of the charges, he's dropping the ones that he realized (and which a judge would have clearly ruled pre-trial) that he would never be able to prove the elements of beyond a reasonable doubt. The gag order was issued by the judge, not the prosecutor, so all relevant actions, including the amending of or dropping of charges, are thereby gagged.

Comment: Assuming the population you're studying is very large, it is 1.96*sqrt((p*(1-p))/n) where p is the proportion of the result you're looking at, n is the sample size and 1.96 is the number of standard deviations from the mean for 95% confidence, ie the distance you have to go out from the center of the normal distribution to hit the 2.5% tails (this number would be different if you were looking for the error rate at a different confidence level).  

Note something that people often don't realize and that is that p(1-p) is a maximum for p=0.5 (0.25), so the error a result is subject to is a maximum when the result you're measuring is 50%... the closer you move to measuring something closer to 0% or 100%, the smaller your error band gets.  So strictly speaking, the error rate quoted for a survey is a maximum MOE, and different results in the same survey have different errors.

Alternatively, do it the easy way and plug your numbers into any number of online margin of error calculators. ;-)

Comment: DrWill

There is no valid, peer-reviewed scientific evidence of any advere effect on IQ from optimally fluoridated water.  The Harvard meta-analysis was of 27 Chinese studies of the effects of high levels of fluoride in the well-water of various Chinese, Mongolian, and Iranian villages.  Not only were the fluoride levels not applicable to fluoridated water in the US, by the admission of the Harvard reviewers themselves, these studies had key information missing, questionable methodologies, and inadequate controls for confounders.  They were so seriously flawed that the Harvard reviewers, Choi and Grandjran, issued a public statement in 2013 stating that no conclusions could be drawn about fluoridated water in the US, from these studies.

Broadbent, et al. concluded in 2014:

"These findings do not support the assertion that fluoride in the context of CWF programs is neurotoxic"

Steven D. Slott, DDS

Comment: The advisor says.

'Even though Helen has stated that she can tolerate some risk, a four-year time-horizon until she buys a house makes investing her savings earmarked for the down payment in market-based securities such as stocks or bonds unadvisable, Ms. Ulmer says. “The risk of a market decrease over a four-year time horizon could jeopardize her principal and the goal of a 20-per-cent down payment by 2021.”'

Then the advisor says to put her down payment money into a savings account at 1%.

Yes, if interest rates go up the value of a bond drops, but only if you are trying to sell it before it matures.  A quick check on my broker's site shows a number of  'A' and higher rated bonds that mature in 2021 that are paying just under 2%.

Why not buy these and double your return?  The value of the bond does not drop if you hold until maturity, and you get an very safe return double the return on a savings account.

Comment: Your assumption would be wrong if it applies to Chinese students.  Their university entrance marks are determined by a two-day exam called the Gaokao, which is considered to be one of the hardest exams in the world.  Chinese students study years for this exam, regardless of wealth.  Students who do not prove their academic standing doing the Gaokao have to meet requirements through other recognized exams, such as the ACT or SAT, or meet requirements of a recognized program, such as a Canadian provincial high school diploma.  You would be right to say that these students are not elite by the standards of the country from which they come, but compared to Canadian students, most of them probably are.

Comment: By Canadian convention the Liberals will be given the first chance to govern even if the Greens (or NDP) don't prop them up.  They will be allowed to govern until they are defeated in a confidence motion.

If/when the Liberals are defeated in a confidence motion it is then up to the Lieutenant Governor's discretion to decide if she wants to allow the NDP a chance to form a government (including the option of forming a coalition with the Greens) or if another election should be called.

Long story short, there is no guarantee that the NDP and Greens will get a chance to form a coalition, and even if they do such coalitions have had a pretty rocky history in Canada.

Comment: FYI - The Ko'olauloa Health Center is Federally Qualified Community Health Center.  It is one of 15 FQCHCs operating in Hawaii, mostly in rural or neighbor island communities.  Supported primarily by federal grants and subsidies, these FQCHCs serve as the backbone for the delivery of primary health care services as the high cost of living drives our private practice doctors and dentists out of rural communities in Hawaii. 

Our State cannot afford to lose these FQCHCs as they serve as the medical life lines for many of our communities, neighbors and friends.  A loss of funding from the Federal government is a real fear for those communities.  So to the Governor, Attorney General, Congressmen, and other elected leaders, please do not endanger the lives of our friends, neighbors and families by trying to make political points by "sticking it to" President Trump.  Your egos may be blown up by tweeting snide remarks and comments, but put many people in peril with your pointed remarks.

Comment: I have a problem with false assumptions, not deductions. 

Pass a test to exercise a constitutional right? I don't think that will pass muster. Would you also require a test, say, for literacy, to vote? 

How would you force gun owners to register their existing weapons? Search and seizure? That won't fly either, but for EVERY new purchase? Absolutely. 

How about extending liability laws in some manner: If a gun is used in a murder and the seller broke some law in getting the killer the weapon, the seller can also be charged as an accessory? 

How about a massive, voluntary buy back program that pays three or four times a weapon's worth? Won't eliminate guns, but would drive costs sky high so that even the black market guns would be out of reach of low-level bad guys and most suicidal folks. This could even be done with private funds. 

How about a new organization to compete with the NRA? One for "good" gun owners that actually focuses on training and safety?

Comment: One final thought on the soulless entity otherwise known as Sound Transit - they remind me of Gene Hackman's soulless overlord in the mediocre yet strangely watchable Sam Raimi Western, The Quick and The Dead. Yet somehow, you managed to find the money to hire a gunfighter to kill me. If ya got so much money, I'm just gonna have to take some more!"

Sound familiar?

Comment: Donald Trump's extensive business dealings around the globe have focused attention on an obscure provision of the Constitution... the Emoluments Clause. 

The Foreign Emoluments Clause can be found in Article I, Section 9 of the Constitution. It provides that "no Person holding any Office of Profit or Trust under [the United States] shall, without Consent of Congress, accept ... any present, Emolument, Office, or Title, of any kind whatever, from any King, Prince, or foreign State."

Trump's companies do deal with businesses that are controlled or influenced by foreign government officials. Legal experts say the potential for constitutional violations is high.

The Bank of China is a lender for one of Trump's buildings in Midtown Manhattan. If the Bank of China were to offer Trump's company a favorable interest rate on that loan after he takes office, it might raise an Emoluments Clause issue.

Comment: The insecticides you are thinking of are applied before flowering and after the nectar has dried up. The hives are trucked in and then out. Otherwise, the honey bees would be killed. They live very stressful lives here. Back during the 2005 bee die-off, it was found a batch of diseased queens had been shipped in from Australia.

But we do have bumble bees. A real study would check the native populations for effects.

Comment: A "Medicare For All" form of health insurance would be best for the overwhelming majority of our citizens.  I am in Medicare and it is a great program.  I get to pick my own doctor and hospital, which is important to me.  Although my personal physician does not accept Medicare payments his bills are manageable.  All the big bills come from specialists and hospitals, including Johns Hopkins and the Cleveland Clinic, and they all accept Medicare.  The medicare premiums are manageable and I would gladly pay more to keep Medicare solvent.  

The problems with our current private healthcare system are that the insurance company administrative costs consume about 25 percent of each dollar spend, the pharmaceutical industry is screwing us big time with their high drug prices and excessive profits, and the obscene levels of compensation for top executives of these companies.  A "Medicare for All"  program would allow the government to bargain down prices and eliminate excessive compensation.

Comment: It actually doesn't. It says that because a "well-regulated," which is a term of art that, at the time (thus establishing the authors' intent) meant both well-equipped but also "in good working order" (as a "well-regulated clock") militia is necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the -people- (not "the militia" nor "the state") to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed.

The Amendment says nothing about -membership- in such a militia, nor that the militia is the sole reason for the right, merely the political one (given it is a political document). Which makes sense because a militia is not a standing army but rather is made up of individual people who, when called up, would need to already be armed and competent with their individually owned weapons.

Because well-read voters are necessary to the good government of a free state, the right of the people to keep and read books shall not be infringed is a parallel phrasing. Voting's merely one reason to protect books.

Comment: "At which point, the House leadership should present a repeal-and-replace that includes such phase-three provisions as tort reform and permitting the buying of insurance across state lines, both of which would significantly lower costs."

I seriously doubt it. I don't think lawsuits are a big factor in health care costs. Permitting the buying of insurance across state lines removes all state controls and create national monopolies, which would probably lead to higher premiums and worse benefits.

I do agree that the ACA is an awkward Rube Goldberg (look it up if you're young) contraption that keeps insurance companies in the loop and will probably self-destruct. We can't afford them. A single-payer system would be much simpler, more efficient, and a lot less expensive. It's the system used by other industrialized democracies.

Health Care for All Oregon -- http://hcao.org -- is working on setting up a state single-payer system.

So her statements are open to criticism, but to an intelligent, nuanced criticism, not a witch-hunt.

Comment: I live in BC's Lower Mainland and various communities determined living wages to be from $21 to $23 per hour. When Christy Clark of the Faux Liberals was in power, one of the things she did was put up the minimum wage from $8.00 (since 2001), in three $0.75 an hour increases over a year from Mat 2011 to 2012. There was one business group which condemned the policy and claimed it would result in the loss of over 50,000 jobs. I am not aware of any university studies on the impact and I've seen no follow-up. At the time I thought the claim of 50,000 jobs lost was an astonishing exaggeration. When you look at the population of BC, the working population, etc., that would suggest the loss of a huge proportion (i.e. a quarter to a half) of minimum wage jobs. I don't think that ever happened.

As for this study in Seattle, it has been criticized and I have no sense where the dust will settle as the results are so politically hot.

Comment: This column does an excellent job of capturing the facts. What I would add is this. APPEARANCES  matter. In government, appearances either build or erode trust. 
This is the reason elected officials seeking to be elected and trusted pledge to be transparent and inclusive. Even the fuzzy Ethics Code of the City of FW states "Each Employee is expected to act in accordance with all laws and ethics that may apply to his or her position, as well as striving to avoid even an appearance of impropriety in the conduct of his or her office or business". The appearances of this cozy relationship give great pause and raises many questions. The City of FW needs to seriously examine how they wish to be viewed by the public. And then they need to act in accordance with those values and principles. In general, I'm one of those who believe the majority of public employees strive to provide the best services possible to the public. In this case, something went wrong.  Deeply concerning to say the least.

Comment: We have an afterschool program at the school where I teach.  We routinely take any children not picked up after school to the building where this program takes place.  Parents rarely call if they are going to use this service - they know this program exists and that we take the child there after carpool is over.  On any given day, there are any number of children there - kids who routinely go there, as well as kids who haven't been picked up, usually because their parents are late.  If the office called all the kids who weren't expected there, they'd be on the phone for a long time, and usually by the time they got to a certain parent, they would have already picked up their child!
